qas.question: What can cause the doubling of chromosome pairs?
Are the plants produced by this error, able to reproduce?
Can these plants cross breed with the parent population of plants?
What happens to these new plants if they are able to reproduce?
What is a yellow example of a sterile,hybrid plant with no seeds?

context: Most sexually reproducing organisms are diploid, with paired chromosomes, but doubling of their chromosome number may occur due to <a0_0>errors in cytokinesis<a0_0/>. This can occur early in development to produce an autopolyploid or partly autopolyploid organism, or during normal processes of cellular differentiation to produce some cell types that are polyploid (endopolyploidy), or during gamete formation. An allopolyploid plant may result from a hybridisation event between two different species. Both autopolyploid and allopolyploid plants can <a1_0>often reproduce normally<a1_0/>, but may be <a2_0>unable to cross-breed successfully<a2_0/> with the parent population because there is a mismatch in chromosome numbers. These plants that are reproductively isolated from the parent species but live within the same geographical area, may be sufficiently successful to <a3_0>form a new species<a3_0/>. Some otherwise sterile plant polyploids can still reproduce vegetatively or by seed apomixis, forming clonal populations of identical individuals. Durum wheat is a fertile tetraploid allopolyploid, while bread wheat is a fertile hexaploid. The <a4_0>commercial banana<a4_0/> is an example of a sterile, seedless triploid hybrid. Common dandelion is a triploid that produces viable seeds by apomictic seed.
